Why did the documentation left out the whole unsubscribing from route params subscription from the docs. And yet still includes phrases such as "we\'ll feed the Observable directly into our template using the AsyncPipe, which will handle unsubscribing from the Observable for us when the component is destroyed" or "The router offers a Snapshot alternative that gives us the initial value of the route parameters. We don\'t need to subscribe or unsubscribe. It\'s much simpler to write and read:". These lead one to believe that subscription should be done. But the removal of any reference about that (unlike previously) would indicate that unsubscribing onDestroy is no longer necessary
PEsteves8: mm because u don't need to unsubscribe from it?

I appreciate your response, but I feel you didn\'t really read what I asked. Why does the documentation include expressions like "the AsyncPipe, which will handle unsubscribing from the Observable for us" and "a Snapshot alternative that gives us the initial value of the route parameters. We don\'t need to subscribe or unsubscribe."
if unsubscription it not needed anyway?
Why refer that snapshot alternative and async pipe make it unnecessary to unsubscribe, if that what it already happens anyway
(maybe I wasn't clear before, sorry)
PEsteves8: file an issue on [<-LINK->] if something is not clear for u. we do not write docs
snapshot is a plain object
this is why u don't need to subscibe/unsubscribe
it's not even possible
and u don't need to unsubscribe from route observables in general
because every component has it's own instance of ActivatedRoute

Right... I know you don't right docs. But I was hoping you were able to help out understanding angular's features. I know that you don't unsubscribe snapshot, that's pretty easy to understand. My point is, why the emphasis on the wonders of using methods that allows to skip unsubscribing, if that already happens?

And I\'m just going to assume that that emphasis shouldn\'t be there and that it\'s a bit misleading. and "We don\'t need to subscribe or unsubscribe", could be changed to just "We don\'t need to subscribe"
*write docs
file an issue on https://github.com/angular/angular.io/issues and they will explain/change it better
ok
PEsteves8: they emphasize it, because it is important... For me it's absolutly clear and logical
base rule is: when you subscribe then you also need to unsubscribe... all other thins are exceptions from that rule
dklmuc: Ah yes. But I was told here that router params unsubscribe is done anyway on component destruction, without any need to do it explicitly using the onDestroy hook.
PEsteves8: really? that's new for me...

dklmuc: I was told that here, after I asked why the recommendation to unsubscribe using the onDestroy hook was removed from the docs. But I still feel a bit confused from the things I just asked a couple of minutes ago.
PEsteves8: confusion always depends who you ask...
I'll just focus more on the docs repo for things like these
PEsteves8: the skill level of some people is really high, but their level of social skills is exactly the opposite...

dklmuc: In case you\'re interested, regarding the whole router params unsubscribing thing from yesterday, I finally got clarification here: [<-LINK->] Summarizing: "I see your point. Not having to unsubscribe was a virtue of snapshot. Now it isn\'t. Not having to subscribe remains a snapshot virtue. I\'ll update prose accordingly." :D

Hello guys,

is this a bug, or do you know a workaround for the following problem? Imagine you have the following webcomponent: [<-CODE->]. The component reads the text inside the script tag and sends it to a server which evaluates the result. The webcomponent should be embedded in an Angular App. It is no Angular component and should just rendered as is. It has contain a script tag, because 'text/plain' allows it not to be parsed as html and like this it is possible for expressions to contain characters like < as in var1 < var2 without being recognized as the beginning of a html tag. But Angular deletes all script tags inside templates, also those with text/plain. I read, that this is because you shouldn't mix JavaScript with Angular Templates, but this is just plain text.  Is there a workaround. Is it a bug?
@AlexanderJohr ,here you go. Let me know if this answers your question. [<-LINK->]

I've a really weird scrolling bug. When I want to scroll down on a page, right after switching to it, the page automaticly scrolls up. Hey, ran into an interesting bug, and I’m not sure this is just my problem, or ng-bootstrap’s problem, or a best practices problem, or some combination. Here is an example of the bugged code, which came indirectly from a project I’m working on that inexplicably broke between ng-bootstrap alpha 5 and 6: [<-LINK->]
what is it anyway i have no idea lol, lemme check. oh an editor. just use a textarea! :P.
that's horrible
See the problem? The issue was *ngFor = “let dropdown of menu”. dropdown clashed with a variable name in the ngbDropdown package.
So the question is: should we have known better than to use dropdown as a name? should ng-bootstrap be prefixing its local variables so that this sort of thing won’t be an issue?
@karptonite technically it needs a dash to be valid html anyway, i suggest prefixing your own components
@karptonite oh, the variable name clashed? sorry i misread though it was component name clash
Yes.
hah, funny
variable name clashed. it took me an embarrassingly long time to figure that out.
@karptonite first time seeing a case like this, i think nobody prefixes their variable names. it's amazing you did figure it out, it'd never cross my mind lol.
how can dat clash anyway? that variable is scoped to the template
I’m open to theories, but that is definitely the issue.
note that I use dropdown inside the ngbDropdownToggle element, and that is where the clash happens, I think.
it's still very weird, i don't think that's intended behvaiour. it should still give you a sensible error
So is this an Angular bug?
well i cannot speak for the team, but from what you described, i'd totally say it needs some working. at the very least, a sensibile error message
If so, I’d like to report it properly, but I don’t know what a good minimal example would be.
maybe wait to see if someone can figure out exactly how the clash is happening first, since i'm kinda dumbfounded
